channel.title: NYT > Health
channel.copyright: Copyright 2009 The New York Times Company

item.title: Some Stem Cell Research Limits Lifted
item.description: The proposed guideline announced by the Obama administration will please many but not all scientists.
item.dc:creator: By GARDINER HARRIS

item.title: Subsidy Plan Seeks to Cut Malaria Drug Cost
item.description: International health agencies and European governments want to get critical antimalarial medication into the hands of the poor for as little as a nickel wholesale.
item.dc:creator: By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.
item.category: Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria

item.title: Guidance Counselor | Learning Disabilities: Stepping Up to the Challenge
item.description: For students with attention deficit disorder, the transition to college can be shaky.
item.dc:creator: By TARA PARKER-POPE

item.title: Going Against the Trend, Nevada Lawmakers Consider Easing the State’s Ban on Smoking
item.description: The Nevada Senate advanced a measure that would allow smoking in taverns that serve food after owners complained of falling gambling revenue.
item.dc:creator: By STEVE FRIESS

item.title: Patient Money: Some Caveats About Keeping Your Own Electronic Health Records
item.media:description: “We’ve got a long way to go” before digital health files are widespread, said Dr. Ashish Jha, an associate professor at Harvard who has been involved in several studies on such records.
item.media:credit: Jodi Hilton for The New York Times
item.description: Much work remains to be done before detailed medical files and seamless communication can improve the quality of health care.
item.dc:creator: By WALECIA KONRAD

item.title: A Hard-Charging Doctor on Obama’s Team
item.media:description: Dr. Ezekiel J. Emanuel looks at health care issues from a physician’s perspective. His brother Rahm is President Obama’s White House chief of staff.
item.description: With a black belt in tae kwon do and a degree in philosophy, Dr. Ezekiel Emanuel brings an unorthodox perspective to President Obama’s health care effort.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT PEAR

item.title: Recipes for Health: Miso Soup With Tofu
item.media:credit: Andrew Scrivani for The New York Times
item.description: A version of the Japanese classic, this time with more vegetables.
item.dc:creator: By MARTHA ROSE SHULMAN

item.title: Task to Aid Self-Esteem Lifts Grades for Some
item.description: The students who benefited most were blacks who were doing poorly, the study found.
item.dc:creator: By BENEDICT CAREY

item.title: A Cheap, Fast and Possibly Deadly Route to Beauty
item.description: Officials fear that a growing number of women are using illegal silicone injections instead of cosmetic surgery.
item.dc:creator: By ANEMONA HARTOCOLLIS and CHRISTINA DAVIDSON

item.title: Glaxo and Pfizer Join Forces to Develop and Market H.I.V. Drugs
item.description: The pharmaceutical giants GlaxoSmithKline and Pfizer said they would form a specialty company to research, develop and market treatments for H.I.V.
item.dc:creator: By NATASHA SINGER

item.title: Genes Show Limited Value in Predicting Diseases
item.description: The genetic analysis of common disease is turning out to be a lot more complex than expected, according to new commentary.
item.dc:creator: By NICHOLAS WADE

item.title: To Fill Food Safety Gap, Processors Pay Inspectors
item.media:description: A worker spraying chlorinated water to kill germs on crops at a Church Brothers field in Huron, Calif.
item.media:credit: Peter DaSilva for The New York Times
item.description: Safety scares prompted California’s so-called leafy greens industry to pay for inspections that the F.D.A. rarely does.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW MARTIN

item.title: Skin Deep: Many Cutbacks but Not for Straight Teeth
item.description: Even in a recession, parents see braces for their children as an investment in the future.
item.dc:creator: By CATHERINE SAINT LOUIS

item.title: Morning Rounds: Defective Fitness Balls, H.I.V. in Prisons and Obese Airline Passengers
item.description: Health news from around the Web.
item.dc:creator: By RONI CARYN RABIN

item.title: I.Q. Harmed by Epilepsy Drug in Utero
item.description: Children of women who took valproate during pregnancy scored lower on I.Q. tests than similar children not exposed to the drug, researchers found.
item.dc:creator: By RONI CARYN RABIN

item.title: Study Finds Risk of Dementia Increases After Hypoglycemia
item.description: A study of older patients with Type 2 diabetes found that those who had experienced a serious episode of hypoglycemia were at higher risk for developing dementia.
item.dc:creator: By RONI CARYN RABIN
item.category: Journal of the American Medical Assn

item.title: Promising Test for Dendreon’s Prostate Cancer Drug
item.description: A prostate cancer drug developed by the biotechnology company Dendreon prolonged the lives of men in a decisive clinical trial, the company said.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW POLLACK

item.title: Prenatal Testing of Thyroid Is Debated
item.media:description: DEPICTIONRenaissance artists unwittingly captured links between motherhood and thyroid trouble by showing goiters.
item.description: Most doctors’ groups have not endorsed universal prenatal thyroid screening, but advocates of routine testing see no need to wait for more answers.
item.dc:creator: By INGFEI CHEN

item.title: Vital Signs: Patterns: Living Near a Highway Linked to Arthritis
item.description: Only 1 percent of the population is affected by rheumatoid arthritis, but living near a highway seems to increase your risk.
item.dc:creator: By NICHOLAS BAKALAR

item.title: Jail Time Increases Odds of Hypertension, Researchers Find
item.description: Development of hypertension in former inmates was not related to the usual risk factors, like smoking and alcohol use, a study has found.
item.dc:creator: By RONI CARYN RABIN

item.title: Global Update: AIDS: Earlier Drug Treatment for AIDS Saves More Lives, Study Finds
item.description: Researchers have identified a new benchmark for starting drug treatment for AIDS, according to a new report.
item.dc:creator: By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.

item.title: First Mention: Alzheimer’s Disease
item.media:description: LABELSAlois Alzheimer wrote of pre-senile dementia.
item.description: Alois Alzheimer was the first to note the characteristics of what came to be known as Alzheimer’s disease in a young woman.
item.dc:creator: By NICHOLAS BAKALAR

item.title: Showdown at the Coffee Shop
item.media:description: BATTLING FOR YOUR TASTE BUDSFrom left, Sweet ’N Low (saccharin), Splenda (sucralose), Equal (aspartame) and a newcomer, Truvia (stevia), share a market of often impassioned fans.
item.description: The world of artificial sweeteners is changing as a new player, dressed in green, hopes to shift the balance of power.
item.dc:creator: By KIM SEVERSON

item.title: Recipes for Health: Spicy Stir-Fried Tofu With Bok Choy or Baby Broccoli
item.media:credit: Andrew Scrivani for The New York Times
item.description: A nutrient-rich stir-fry that makes for a zesty entree.
item.dc:creator: By MARTHA ROSE SHULMAN

item.title: Vital Signs: Regimens: Tai Chi Shows Promise as a Stroke Therapy
item.description: Tai chi may improve the balance of stroke patients, a new study shows.
item.dc:creator: By ERIC NAGOURNEY

item.title: Vital Signs: Children: Early Swim Lessons May Reduce Drowning
item.description: Swimming lessons for children ages 1 to 4 may help reduce the risk of drowning, says a new study.
item.dc:creator: By ERIC NAGOURNEY

item.title: Help Is Sought for West Virginia Health System
item.description: Amid reports that characterized West Virginia’s system for treating the mentally ill as one of the worst in the country, the state’s legislature approved a $6 million increase in financing.
item.dc:creator: By SEAN D. HAMILL

item.title: Quest to Pay $302 Million in Marketing Case
item.description: Quest Diagnostics will pay $302 million and one of its business units will plead guilty to misleading marketing practices as part of a settlement with the federal government.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: As Pills Treat Cancer, Insurance Lags Behind
item.media:description: Chuck Stauffer’s insurance covered hardly any of the cost of the cancer pills the doctor prescribed for him to take at home.
item.media:credit: Brian Lee for The New York Times
item.description: Pills are the new wave in cancer treatment, but payment coverage is often behind the times.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW POLLACK

item.title: Overseer of Medical Trials, Under F.D.A. Pressure, Agrees to Suspension
item.description: A Colorado company that approved a make-believe clinical trial run by doctors who did not exist agreed to suspend approving federally regulated medical studies.
item.dc:creator: By BARRY MEIER

item.title: Taking a Page, and a Pen, From Makers of Medicines
item.media:description: Sharraine Franklin, a city worker known as a detailer, brings literature for Dr. Muhammad Sanni Adam to give to his patients.
item.description: New York City is using representatives known as detailers to conduct public health campaigns drawing on the techniques of drug company salespeople.
item.dc:creator: By ANEMONA HARTOCOLLIS

item.title: Personal Health: Keeping Those Bed Bugs From Biting
item.description: Bed bug infestations may be on the rise. What can you do to prevent being bitten?
item.dc:creator: By JANE E. BRODY

item.title: Really?: The Claim: Nasal Irrigation Can Ease Allergy Symptoms
item.description: Can a “neti pot” help to reduce suffering during allergy season?
item.dc:creator: By ANAHAD O’CONNOR

item.title: Well: Stomach Bug Crystallizes an Antibiotic Threat
item.description: Drugs that solve one problem, only to open the door to another.
item.dc:creator: By TARA PARKER-POPE

item.title: Doctor and Patient: Life and Death on the Operating Table
item.description: Transplant surgeon Dr. Thomas E. Starzl, a pioneer of modern medicine, offers advice for doctors and patients.
item.dc:creator: By PAULINE W. CHEN, M.D.

item.title: Cases: A City of Strangers and Kindness
item.description: A Parkinson’s patient finds help when the drugs wear off.
item.dc:creator: By DARCY HELLER STERNBERG

item.title: Recession Anxiety Seeps Into Everyday Lives
item.media:description: From left, Monica Ferrari, Victoria Villalba and Line Bovery at a meditation class in Florida.
item.media:credit: Richard Patterson for The New York Times
item.description: Experts see signs that stress is becoming more common as a result of the economic downturn.
item.dc:creator: By PAM BELLUCK

item.title: Cases: A Roller Coaster to Acceptance of a Son’s Autism
item.media:description: HIS OWN WAY Jonah Lehmann, 25, who has autism, with the manager of his group home, Darlene Manuta.
item.description: When told their son’s autism was “untreatable,” two parents stepped into action.
item.dc:creator: By ANNIE LUBLINER LEHMANN

item.title: Cases: Comforter and Comforted in an Unfolding Mystery
item.description: In a bedside companion, a human story beyond illness and treatment.
item.dc:creator: By NELL BURGER KIRST

item.title: Mind: Accepting the Risks in Creating Confident Doctors
item.description: Both medical students and patients seem to understand that a lot of practice, sprinkled with a few errors, is necessary to make a medical expert.
item.dc:creator: By RICHARD A. FRIEDMAN, M.D.
